text: Yeah, well, I guess we're here out of fear, and that is fear that somebody will be killed because of the behavior of these young people.  nearly all had near misses with them on the road. Our family members, my son, Sally's stepdaughter, have all had near misses and had to drive through huge crowds of young people. 50 plus cars parked at the intersection between Arapuni Road and Rotonata Road. So we're also very concerned about the destruction of our reserves.  skidding cars and vandalism of the amenities and also road signage being knocked over all over the place and there's a must be a huge cost to the ratepayer there to repair all that damage. Our local intersections are covered in black tyre rubber and some are so badly damaged that the road markings are completely obliterated.  Vast quantities of litter are being left behind at these intersections and on our reserves. Alcohol containers, drug-taking paraphernalia and general rubbish. And we're very concerned about the threatening behaviour of these people when they're confronted by us, the residents, by Comsafe or the police. And moving on to the police,  which has already been raised by the mayor, I know, is the inability of police to respond in a timely manner because we're in a rural location and the police just do not seem to be adequately resourced to deal with this issue promptly. So, the things we're requesting, on our own road here at Arapuni Lake Road, we're requesting that the speed limit be reduced from 100 kilometres an hour to 50 kilometres an hour.  And there's shortly going to be nine houses here within a very short distance of each other and obviously nine driveways. People zooming past at 100 kilometers an hour with boats. You know, and it's just not safe to walk down our own road, especially at the weekend.  We'd like some lockable, vandal-proof gates on Bulmer and Arapuni landings to prevent the gathering of these youths at night. I notice in Cambridge, on the mighty River Domain, beside Lake Carapiro, they've got some very spectacular gates and ramps, speed humps, to stop people entering at night.  more than happy to take responsibility for locking and unlocking those gates at agreed times. We like CCTV cameras so we can record number plates of people coming down to the landings because quite often the people that come down here in the evenings do the burnouts and skids on the way out. So it's helpful to have those number plates before they start.  calming measures at the intersection of Arapuni, Rotorata and Bulmer roads and these need to be the type of the raised medium type. This is so that they can't be removed by these vandals because they will remove them if it's possible to remove them. I'll hand over to Sally and she can tell you what we've already done.

text: So my involvement with this has come about mainly through the liaison I have with CommSafe. Historically, the 111 calls that come through for not just this area don't necessarily come to me. But just over several conversations with Mandy, it became quite apparent that there was an issue out there.  Working with the community, we're trying to come up with a bit of an action plan from the policing perspective. A couple of points that were raised from Shelly and Leslie, it's not entirely safe for them to be having to go out there and collect that information in the first place. And what's practically, that's what the police need. The burden of proof to get someone to court and to take their car is fairly high.  in the form of statements, and when they're out there taking videos and photographs of these guys, it makes them targets. I mean, Sally's house is right next to that landing, and they all know that she lives there, and if they see her taking footage of them doing it and passing it off to us, she becomes a target, and we need to take that away from, take that burden off her somehow. The residents of Pukeatua have funded  a camera system, which I believe is partway through implementation at the moment, which will go a long way to helping with that. Our big problem from the police is resourcing. If there's 50 or 60 cars out there, it's just not safe to send one lone patrol car out there. And if we do happen to blunder across something along those lines,  we're not gonna get out of the car and start stopping every single person and getting their details. And we need to see them doing burnouts effectively for us to be able to act. Often, if we do get a car out there, they're parked up on the side of the road. And I think a method of control for that would be around the cruising part of the bylaw. For example, Christchurch has one where I think it's 90 days, they slap a sticker on the car,  and if it's seen within 90 days, we can impound the car, that's probably the biggest punishment they're gonna get, losing their car for 28 days, and that's at their cost. They don't pay their court fines, that'll be converted to community service down the track, but when they lose their car, they will get it out, especially if it's mum and dad's car. So that's probably the biggest thing that I would like to see change, is having something added into the bylaw to prevent them from parking up  in those places in the first place. Because from there, we've got all sorts of evidence gathering. Most Fonterra tankers that frequent that area, they all have dash cam, for example. So we've got that evidence. And again, it takes it away from Sally and the other residents down there from having to do it themselves. And the other part of it is the environmental issues down there. For example, I went down on a,  a couple of weeks ago, and all of those wooden barriers around that gravel pit on the corner of Rodanata Road, they're all just hacked up and have been used for firewood. That's ratepayers' bloody firewood, in my view. A steel armco would go a long way to fixing that up, all that cheese grater stuff, and maybe gating up that gravel pit so they can't access it in the first place, and then having an armco on either side of the road  Recently, I took a prisoner up to Spring Hill and at the on-ramp, off-ramp there, off the motorway, that was the biggest spot in New Zealand for boy racer activity until about 12 months ago. You'd get three or 400 cars from all over the upper North Island congregating there most Saturdays and Sundays, sorry, Fridays and Saturdays. And the method to fix that was simply a raised traffic island.  and for the on-ramp and in the middle of the road, it took the environment away from them so they can't do burnouts there. And the intersection is largely fixed now, and they haven't really had to spend a lot of dollars to keep it fixed. So those are the sort of things that I think we could look at in this area and going forward, you know, over time, other areas where they like to congregate.  I don't think I've got anything else off the top of my head at the moment.
